instruction: What metric was chosen in the related study for real-time detection of pathogen-specific molecular fingerprint VOCs in food safety investigations, and how far can this metric go in predicting complex VOC mixtures?

instruction: What machine learning algorithms were used to assist in the extraction of molecular information from the raw Raman spectra in the development of the novel fiber-optic-based portable Raman probe for real-time detection of pathogen-specific molecular fingerprint VOCs in food safety investigations?

instruction: Can the developed ML-assisted Raman probe using spectral analysis be considered a superior method compared to traditional detection methods for the rapid on-site detection of complex chemical mixtures in food safety investigations?
Output: Yes, the developed ML-assisted Raman probe using spectral analysis can be considered a superior method compared to traditional detection methods for the rapid on-site detection of complex chemical mixtures in food safety investigations. This is because the ML-assisted Raman probe offers several advantages over traditional methods, including high selectivity and sensitivity, simple operation at a relatively low cost, and the ability to accurately predict complex VOC mixtures even at high dilution folds. Additionally, the probe is portable, allows for non-contact operation, and provides precise classification of foodborne pathogen VOCs. These advantages make the ML-assisted Raman probe a more efficient and accurate tool for detecting and identifying foodborne pathogens in real-time, thereby enhancing food safety investigations.
